column4: PVH President Larsson to take over as CEO in February
column5: (Reuters) - Tommy Hilfiger owner PVH Corp PVH.N said on Wednesday President Stefan Larsson would replace Manny Chirico as chief executive officer in February.
column6: Larsson, a former CEO of Ralph Lauren Corp RL.N, joined PVH in June last year, taking on the job of overseeing the company's various brands such as Van Heusen, Calvin Kelin, as well as Tommy Hilfiger.
column7: His appointment was part of PVH’s plan to find a successor to Chirico, who has been at the helm since 2006.
column8: Larsson has already been at the forefront of major decisions PVH has taken to tackle the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, including cutting hundreds of jobs in North America and shuttering 162 retail stores.
column9: Chirico, 63, will continue to serve as the company’s chairman, PVH said.

column4: PVH names company President Larsson as CEO
column5: Sept 30 (Reuters) - Tommy Hilfiger owner PVH Corp said on Wednesday President Stefan Larsson will replace Manny Chirico as chief executive officer in February.
column6: Chirico, 63, will continue to serve as the company’s chairman, PVH said. (Reporting by Uday Sampath in Bengaluru; Editing by Aditya Soni)

column4: PVH posts surprise profit as stay-at-home lifts casual clothing demand
column5: (Reuters) - PVH Corp PVH.N reported a surprise quarterly profit on Wednesday, as the apparel retailer benefited from strong demand for comfortable and casual clothing during the coronavirus-led shift to work from home, sending its shares up over 4%.
column6: The Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger owner also projected encouraging sales trends in China and Europe for the coming months and forecast revenue in the second half of its fiscal year to decline 25%, smaller than the 33% drop it posted in the second quarter.
column7: The company’s North American business, however, remains under pressure due to a resurgence in virus infections, a lack of tourist traffic and a fall in shipments to department stores.
column8: PVH, which also owns Van Heusen, reported total revenue of $1.58 billion for the second quarter ended Aug. 2, beating analysts’ estimates of $1.25 billion.
column9: Online sales through its own channels surged 87%.
column10: The company reported an attributable net loss of $51.4 million, or 72 cents per share, compared to a profit of $193.5 million, or $2.58 per share, a year earlier.
column11: Excluding certain items, the company earned 13 cents per share, compared with the average analyst estimate of a loss of $2.43, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.

column4: Calvin Klein owner PVH to cut 450 jobs in North America, shut 162 outlets
column5: (Reuters) - PVH Corp PVH.N said on Tuesday it would cut 450 jobs in North America and shutter 162 retail stores of its business that houses brands such as Van Heusen and IZOD, as the coronavirus crisis wreaks havoc on the apparel industry.
column6: The Tommy Hilfiger and Calvin Klein owner said the layoffs, affecting 12% of its office workforce, would impact three brands and save about $80 million annually.
column7: “The COVID-19 crisis is dramatically reshaping the retail landscape in ways that we believe will be long-term in nature and far-reaching in terms of consumer purchasing behavior,” President Stefan Larsson said.
column8: PVH estimated pre-tax charges of about $80 million over the next 12 months from costs associated with the exit of its heritage brand retail business, which sells the three brands and accounted for 2.6% of its overall revenue in 2019.
column9: “Overall, we see this as a positive development for PVH as the company exits a declining business and reduces costs,” Bernstein analyst Jamie Merriman said.
column10: Spain's Zara, Nordstrom JWN.N and Bath & Body Works have also closed stores in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
column11: (This story corrects syntax in second paragraph)

column5: March 16 (Reuters) - PVH Corp:

column10: * PVH CORP - ALL RETAIL ASSOCIATES AT NORTH AMERICA AND EUROPE TO CONTINUE TO RECEIVE FULL PAY, BENEFITS FOR SCHEDULED SHIFTS DURING TEMPORARY CLOSURE Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: PVH closes most Calvin Klein, Tommy Hilfiger China stores on virus outbreak
column5: (Reuters) - PVH Corp PVH.N said on Wednesday it had temporarily closed majority of its Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger stores in China due to the coronavirus outbreak.
column6: The company said it would have exceeded its fourth-quarter adjusted earnings forecast of at least $1.79 per share, if not for the epidemic, which has killed over 1,100 people.
column7: About 7% of PVH’s revenue comes from Greater China, while the country accounts for about 20% of the company’ global sourcing.

column6: * GREATER CHINA IS EXPECTED TO ACCOUNT FOR APPROXIMATELY 7% OF COMPANY’S 2019 REVENUE
column7: * MAJORITY OF TOTAL CALVIN KLEIN AND TOMMY HILFIGER STORES IN CHINA ARE TEMPORARILY CLOSED DUE TO CORONAVIRUS CONCERNS
column8: * REAFFIRMING ITS GUIDANCE WITH RESPECT TO EARNINGS PER SHARE ON A NON-GAAP BASIS
column9: * ASIA PACIFIC REGION IS EXPECTED TO ACCOUNT FOR APPROXIMATELY 16% OF COMPANY’S 2019 REVENUE
column10: * ABOUT 20% OF COMPANY’S GLOBAL SOURCING IS DERIVED FROM CHINA

column13: * BELIEVES THAT IT WOULD HAVE EXCEEDED ITS NON-GAAP EARNINGS GUIDANCE HAD CORONAVIRUS OUTBREAK NOT OCCURRED

column4: Calvin Klein-owner PVH Corp raises FY profit outlook on strong demand in Europe
column5: (Reuters) - PVH Corp PVH.N raised full-year adjusted profit forecast on Monday after its third-quarter results beat Wall Street expectations, powered by higher demand for its Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger apparel in Europe.
column6: The New York-based company has been trying to attract millennial shoppers by sponsoring social media influencers including 23-year-old model Bella Hadid, singer Billie Eilish and British F1 racer Lewis Hamilton to promote its brands.
column7: Total revenue rose 2.5% to $2.59 billion, above average analysts’ estimate of $2.54 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column8: The company now expects to earn between $9.43 and $9.45 per share for full year 2019 on an adjusted basis, compared with its prior range of $9.30 to $9.40.
column9: Sales at Tommy Hilfiger, its biggest revenue generator, jumped about 10% to $1.24 billion.
column10: Calvin Klein, which is recovering from the fashion missteps it made last year, saw sales rise marginally to $968.9 million.
column11: Excluding items, the company earned $3.10 per share, beating average analysts’ estimate of $3 per share.
column12: Net income attributable to the company fell to $209.2 million, or $2.82 per share in the quarter ended Nov 3, from $243.1 million, or $3.15 per share, a year earlier.
column13: Shares of the New York-based company were slightly up at $101 in aftermarket trading.
column14: (This story adds dropped word demand in headline)

column4: Calvin Klein-owner PVH Corp raises FY profit outlook after third-quarter revenue beat
column5: Nov 25 (Reuters) - PVH Corp’s raised full-year adjusted profit forecast on Monday, after its third-quarter revenue topped Wall Street expectations, powered by higher demand for its Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger apparel in Europe.
column6: Total revenue rose to $2.59 billion from $2.52 billion, above average analysts’ estimate of $2.54 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column7: The company now expects to earn between $9.43 and $9.45 per share for full year 2019, compared with its prior range of $9.30 to $9.40.
column8: Net income attributable to the company fell to $209.2 million, or $2.82 per share, in the quarter ended November 3, from $243.1 million, or $3.15 per share, a year earlier. (Reporting by Praveen Paramasivam in Bengaluru; Editing by Vinay Dwivedi)

column4: PVH cuts profit and revenue forecast as tariffs, Hong Kong protests bite
column5: (Reuters) - PVH Corp PVH.N cut its full-year profit forecast for the second time this year on Wednesday, as the Calvin Klein owner sees pressure from the protracted U.S-China trade tensions and the ongoing protests in Hong Kong.
column6: U.S. retailers have been worried about the cost of the bitter trade war with President Donald Trump’s latest plans to further hike tariffs on Chinese goods imported to the U.S.
column7: The Trump administration on Wednesday made official its extra 5% tariff on $300 billion in Chinese imports and set collection dates of Sept. 1 and Dec. 15.
column8: PVH, which imported about $400 million of inventory from the Asian country last year, said the tariff is expected to hit its earnings by about 20 cents per share in 2019.
column9: Adding to the company’s worries are the increasing promotions by retailers and department store operators in the domestic U.S. market as they grapple with sluggish sales due to a fall in tourist spending as well as the months of political turmoil in Hong Kong.
column10: PVH now expects full-year adjusted profit between $9.30 per share and $9.40 per share compared to prior estimate of $10.20 per share to $10.30 per share.
column11: The company also cut its full-year revenue forecast to about 1% growth, down from its prior outlook of about 3% rise.
column12: Chief Executive Officer Emanuel Chirico said the volatility in the macro environment, the global retail landscape and the continuing escalation of trade tensions between the U.S. and China will cause its business to remain under pressure, as will the ongoing impact of protests in Hong Kong.
column13: Despite the dull outlook, PVH reported better-than-expected quarterly sales boosted by higher demand for its Tommy Hilfiger apparels. Sales in the brand, its biggest revenue generator, rose 8% to $1.11 billion.
column14: Overall, revenue rose 1.3% to $2.36 billion, beating the average analyst estimates of $2.33 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column15: Net income attributable to the company rose to $193.5 million, or $2.58 per share, in the second quarter ended Aug. 4, from $165.2 million, or $2.12 per share, a year earlier.
column16: Excluding items, the company earned $2.10 per share. Analysts, on average, had estimated a profit of $1.88 per share.
column17: Shares of the New-York based company fell marginally in after market trading.

column4: Calvin Klein owner PVH quarterly sales beat estimates
column5: Aug 28 (Reuters) - PVH Corp’s quarterly sales beat Wall Street expectations on Wednesday, helped by higher demand for its Tommy Hilfiger apparels.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose to $193.5 million, or $2.58 per share, in the second quarter ended Aug. 4, from $165.2 million, or $2.12 per share, a year earlier.
column7: Revenue rose 1.3% to $2.36 billion, beating the average analyst estimates of $2.33 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. (Reporting by Soundarya J in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: PVH cuts profit forecast as CEO sees retail softness, shares tank
column5: (Reuters) - PVH Corp cut its annual profit forecast by 10 cents a share on Wednesday as the Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands owner grapples with tariffs and slowing retail growth, exacerbated by weak spending from overseas shoppers in the face of a strong U.S. dollar, sending its shares down 12% after hours.
column6: Escalating trade tensions between China and the United States have emerged as a new headache for U.S. retailers, with a clutch warning that additional tariffs would thin their earnings and margins.
column7: “Looking ahead, the volatile and challenging macroeconomic backdrop has continued into the second quarter, with particular softness across the U.S. and China retail landscape,” Chief Executive Emanuel Chirico said in a statement.
column8: Tariffs on Chinese imports are a concern, as PVH sources a majority of its apparel, footwear and accessories from the Asian country. In 2018, the company imported about $400 million of inventory from China.
column9: Earlier this month, U.S. President Donald Trump escalated the trade war by raising tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods to 25% from 10%. This was in addition to the 25% tariff on $50 billion worth of Chinese imports already in place.
column10: Chirico, in an interview on CNBC, said the latest discussions on tariff and trade issues, which includes proposed tariffs on a further $300 billion worth Chinese imports, was not his main concern.
column11: “That (tariffs) is not the issue going forward... What we’re seeing is a slowdown in growth and a slowdown in retail sales,” he told CNBC, highlighting a slowdown in international tourism in the United States and a strong dollar.
column12: “We’ve really seen some softness in the business,” he said.
column13: PVH projected a 10 cent cut in its full-year adjusted profit per share due to the strong dollar. It now expects 2019 adjusted profit between $10.20 and $10.30 per share, which includes the impact of the latest round of tariffs. Wall Street was expecting $10.42 per share, on average.
column14: “Of course the CEO’s comment is making investors nervous. And he didn’t really mince words, beyond avoiding the tariff subject,” Paula Rosenblum, co-founder of retail research firm RSR Research said.
column15: PVH’s first-quarter revenue rose 1.8% to $2.36 billion, but fell short of analysts’ estimate of $2.37 billion, according to Refinitiv IBES data.
column16: Excluding items, the company earned $2.46 per share, a cent above the average estimate.
column17: Investors will likely hear more comments from Chirico on the analysts call on Thursday.
column18: “We expect the focus for the conference call will be on the cadence of earnings in the remainder of the year,” Bernstein analyst Jamie Merriman said.

column4: CORRECTED-PVH quarterly sales miss estimates
column5: (Corrects headline and paragraph 1 to say sales missed estimates)
column6: May 29 (Reuters) - PVH Corp on Wednesday reported quarterly sales that missed Wall Street estimates, hit by poor performance of its Calvin Klein brand.
column7: Net income attributable to the company fell to $82 million, or $1.08 per share, in the first quarter ended May 5, from $179.4 million, or $2.29 per share, a year earlier.
column8: Revenue rose 1.8% to $2.36 billion, below analysts’ estimate of $2.37 billion, according to Refinitiv IBES data. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: PVH to exit high-end collection of Calvin Klein label
column5: (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp said on Thursday it would exit its high-end collection of Calvin Klein apparel and shut the label’s flagship store on New York’s Madison Avenue, as the fashion line failed to strike a chord with customers.
column6: The company also said it was in talks with its North America apparel partner G-III Apparel Group LTD to license out the brand’s women’s jeans unit.
column7: G-III also operates Tommy Hilfiger women’s business, which helped boost PVH’s strong financial results in the fourth quarter, lifting its shares nearly 18 percent in morning trading.
column8: “We believe this was the right decision for the long-term health of the brand (Calvin Klein) as the existing high-end business was not resonating with our core consumer,” Chief Executive Officer Emanuel Chirico said on a post earnings call.
column9: Fashion missteps at high-end Calvin Klein’s 205W39NYC line of clothing have hit sales in recent quarters as customers baulked at the high prices of the ready-to-wear luxury clothing label that offered oversized sweaters, tie-dyed and silk dresses.
column10: The New York-based company said the decision to exit the label and license out its women’s jeans unit would lower its fiscal 2019 revenue by $100 million.
column11: However, the restructuring of Calvin Klein and the lack of a need for big promotions in its jeans business were likely to improve profit margins in the second half of 2019, the company said.
column12: Chirico said the trade tensions has impacted the company’s retail business in China and the United States.
column13: “Business is softer than we saw the first half of 2018... We’re looking for that trend to continue throughout the first half of 2019,” Chirico said referring to China.
column14: Still, PVH forecast full-year adjusted profit between $10.30 and $10.40 per share, the midpoint of which was above analysts’ expectation of $10.31.

column4: PVH to exit high-end Calvin Klein label
column5: March 28 (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp said on Thursday it would exit the high-end collection of Calvin Klein and shut the label’s flagship store in New York’s Madison Avenue.
column6: The company also said it was in talks with North America apparel partner G-III Apparel Group LTD to take over the brand’s women’s jeans unit.
column7: The company’s sales in recent quarters have been hit by the fashion missteps at the high-end Calvin Klein 205W39NYC line of clothing.
column8: “We believe this was the right decision for the long-term health of the brand as the existing high-end business was not resonating with our core consumer,” Chief Executive Officer Emanuel said on a post earnings call.
column9: PVH shares rose nearly 15 percent in morning trading after reporting better-than-expected results.

column4: PVH forecasts 2019 above estimates on Tommy Hilfiger boost
column5: (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp on Wednesday forecast full-year adjusted profit and sales above Wall Street expectations, banking on higher demand for its Tommy Hilfiger branded apparels and accessories.
column6: Shares of the Calvin Klein owner, which also reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter sales and profit, rose 10 percent after the bell.
column7: The New York-based company has been giving lesser discounts to maintain its premium brand cachet while roping in social media influencers such as Kendall Jenner, Shawn Mendes, and Zendaya to boost Tommy Hilfiger and Calvin Klein brands among millennial and Gen-Z shoppers.
column8: PVH forecast full-year adjusted profit between $10.30 and $10.40 per share, the mid-point of which is above analysts’ estimate of $10.31.
column9: The company also forecast full-year sales growth of 4 percent that translates to about $10.04 billion, above Wall Street estimate of $9.88 billion.
column10: Sales at Tommy Hilfiger, the biggest contributor to PVH’s sales, rose 2.3 percent to $1.2 billion during the reported quarter. The company expects the brand’s sales to grow about 6 percent in full-year 2019.
column11: “The quarter has been stellar. Tommy Hilfiger far outperformed our expectations,” said C.L King and Associates analyst Steven Marotta.
column12: However, sales in Calvin Klein, its second biggest unit, fell 2 percent during the fourth quarter, dragged down by continued softness in the Calvin Klein Jeans business in North America.
column13: The company had announced plans to restructure its Calvin Klein business and relaunch its upscale fashion business under the Calvin Klein 205W39NYC label in January after shoppers balked at higher prices and “fashion forward” products that resulted in underperformance of the brand last quarter.
column14: PVH said it expects Calvin Klein revenue to grow about 2 percent this year.
column15: Net income attributable to the company rose to $158.7 million, or $2.09 per share, in the fourth quarter ended February 3, from $108.5 million, or $1.39 per share, a year earlier.
column16: Net revenue fell 0.6 percent to $2.48 billion as the year-ago quarter included an extra week.
column17: Excluding items, PVH earned $1.84 per share.
column18: Analysts on average had expected a profit of $1.76 on sales of $2.41 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.

column4: PVH quarterly sales beat estimates on Tommy Hilfiger boost
column5: March 27 (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp on Wednesday reported better-than-expected quarterly sales boosted by an increased demand for its Tommy Hilfiger brand, sending its shares up about 7 percent after the bell.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose to $158.7 million, or $2.09 per share, in the fourth quarter ended February 3, from $108.5 million, or $1.39 per share, a year earlier.
column7: Net revenue fell 0.6 percent to $2.48 billion. Analysts on average had expected sales of $2.41 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. (Reporting by Soundarya J in Bengaluru; Editing by Shailesh Kuber)

column4: PVH raises profit forecast, unveils fixes for Calvin Klein
column5: (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp PVH.N on Thursday raised its fourth-quarter adjusted profit forecast and said it would record a $120 million charge for restructuring its Calvin Klein unit.
column6: PVH’s shares, which lost 32 percent of their value in 2018, rose 5.1 percent in extended trading.
column7: Calvin Klein, PVH’s second-biggest segment in sales after Tommy Hilfiger, weighed on PVH’s results in the last quarter after underperformance of its relaunched Calvin Klein 205W39NYC collection.
column8: Calvin Klein said it would rebrand the Calvin Klein 205W39NYC business and shut down its flagship Madison Avenue store this spring as part of the restructuring.
column9: The unit will also consolidate operation of its men’s Calvin Klein Sportswear and Calvin Klein Jeans businesses.
column10: New York-based PVH said it expects to incur the pretax costs related to the Calvin Klein restructuring over the next 12 months.
column11: PVH now expects adjusted profit in the current quarter to be at least $1.75 per share, 15 cents above the high end of its prior guidance range.
column12: The company also forecast full-year adjusted profit of at least $9.50 per share, higher than its previous forecast of $9.33 to $9.35.
column13: PVH said both the forecasts exclude costs related to the restructuring of Calvin Klein.

column4: Calvin Klein owner PVH raises profit forecast
column5: Jan 10 (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp on Thursday raised it fourth-quarter and full-year adjusted profit outlook, citing better performance across its businesses.
column6: The company now expects its full-year adjusted profit to be at least $9.50 per share, compared with its previous forecast of $9.33 to $9.35.
column7: The Calvin-Klein owner said it expects adjusted profit to be at least $1.75 per share in the fourth quarter, 15 cents above the high end of its prior guidance range.
column8: PVH also said it was relaunching its CALVIN KLEIN 205W39NYC under a new name. (Reporting by Soundarya J in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: PVH plans fixes for Calvin Klein, sees strong start to holidays
column5: (Reuters) - PVH Corp PVH.N on Friday allayed investor concerns over its Calvin Klein business and said early holiday sales were above its expectations, sending its shares up as much as 5 percent.
column6: Shares fell 8 percent in extended trade on Thursday after a weakness in the high-end brand in the third quarter led the company to report its first revenue miss in at least two years.
column7: “We went too far, too fast on both fashion and price,” Chief Executive Officer Emanuel Chirico said on a post-earnings call on Friday.
column8: “We’re working on fixing this fashion miss, and we believe that our CK Jeans offering will be much more commercial and fashion-right beginning in 2019,” Chirico said.
column9: The company will also reevaluate spending on Calvin Klein’s 205W39NYC line to improve profit margins in 2019.
column10: Management appears to not only have a better understanding of the driver behind Calvin Klein’s weakness but has executed clear fixes to self-inflicted missteps of the past, J.P. Morgan analyst Matthew Boss said in a note.
column11: Chirico said the company was seeing strong sales at key brands Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger in North America since the start of the holiday season.
column12: “Given commentary that includes accelerating Q4-to-date results and a plan in place to improve Calvin Klein operating margins in FY19, we are taking this opportunity to get incrementally more constructive on the stock,” said C.L. King & Associates’ analyst Steven Marotta, who upgraded his rating to “strong buy” from “buy”.
column13: PVH forecast fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of $1.58 to $1.60 per share, in line with analysts’ expectation, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column14: The company also flagged sluggish consumer traffic in China in the third quarter, compared with the first two quarters, due to a softening economy and an escalating trade dispute between Washington and Beijing.
column15: “We’re still moving but the traffic levels in the store are not what they were in Spring season,” Chirico said.
column16: PVH said it expected $75 million increase in cost of goods if the proposal to raise tariffs to 25 percent is implemented.
column17: “It’s not insignificant,” Chirico said, adding that if the raised tariffs are implemented on Jan. 1 there would be “no time to react”.

column4: PVH falls short of revenue estimates on softness in Calvin Klein
column5: (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp PVH.N reported quarterly revenue on Thursday that missed Wall Street estimates for the first time in at least two years, due to weakness in its Calvin Klein business, sending its shares down nearly 8 percent after-hours.
column6: Calvin Klein, PVH’s second biggest segment in sales after Tommy Hilfiger, relaunched and rebranded its jeans collection bringing a younger feel and a stronger assortment to stores.
column7: Its most recent relaunch - Calvin Klein 205W39NYC - includes ready-to-wear luxury clothing such as oversized sweaters, tie-dyed dresses and plaid trousers.
column8: “We are disappointed by the lack of return on our investments in our Calvin Klein 205W39NYC halo business,” said PVH’s Chief Executive Officer Emanuel Chirico.
column9: Chrico said that some of the relaunched Calvin Klein Jeans “was too elevated” and did not sell as well as planned.
column10: Several retailers, including more affordable brands like Urban Outfitters Inc URBN.O and Gap Inc GPS.N, have launched apparel with styles from the 1990s and boosted their social media presence to attract millennials, their target shoppers.
column11: PVH has also roped in millennial-favorite influencers such as singer Justin Beiber and has collaborated with Amazon.com Inc AMZN.O to set up pop-up stores where shoppers can try their jeans and order them on the online retailer's app.
column12: Despite its efforts, Calvin Klein’s third-quarter earnings, before taxes and interest, fell to $121 million, from $142 million a year earlier, mainly due to an increase in creative and marketing expenditures.
column13: “We believe they (Calvin Klein) didn’t get the mix right in some places such as Macy’s and Amazon, the product might have been too fashion forward...I imagine that will be rectified,” said Jessica Ramirez, a retail analyst with Jane Hali & Associates.
column14: Ramirez said it might have been a hiccup.
column15: “Because it is a relaunch, they are still trying to get it right,” she said.
column16: On the brighter side, PVH’s Tommy Hilfiger, which is banking on retro and streetwear trends, posted a 11 percent rise in quarterly revenue.
column17: PVH raised its full year outlook going into the holiday quarter and now expects adjusted profit between $9.33 to $9.35 per share. It had previously forecast profit of $9.20 to $9.25 per share.
column18: Excluding items, PVH earned $3.21 per share, topping the average estimate of $3.14, according to IBES data from Refinitiv.
column19: Net income attributable to the New York-based company rose 1.6 percent to $243.1 million, or $3.15 per share.
column20: Total revenue rose 7 percent to $2.52 billion, but fell short of analysts’ estimate of $2.53 billion.

column4: Calvin Klein owner PVH Corp misses revenue estimates
column5: Nov 29 (Reuters) - PVH Corp reported on Thursday quarterly revenue that missed analysts’ estimates for the first time in at least two years due to weakness in its Calvin Klein business.
column6: Net income attributable to the New York-based company rose to $243.1 million, or $3.15 per share, in the quarter ended Nov. 4, from $239.2 million, or $3.05 per share, a year earlier.
column7: Total revenue rose 7 percent to $2.52 billion, but fell short of analysts’ estimate of $2.53 billion, according to IBES data from Refinitiv. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila)

column4: Calvin Klein owner PVH profit up 38 percent, forecast raised
column5: (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp PVH.N reported a 38 percent rise in second-quarter profit on Wednesday and raised its earnings forecasts for the year, helped by higher sales of its Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands.
column6: The company now expects earnings of $9.20 to $9.25 per share, compared with its previous forecast of $9.05 to $9.15 per share.
column7: The New York-based apparel maker, like peers Tapestry Inc TPR.N and Ralph Lauren Corp RL.N, has pulled heavily discounted products from department store shelves to regain its premium brand status.
column8: “We are increasing our revenue and earnings guidance for the year, while continuing to take a prudent approach to planning our business in the second half of the year, as we experience increasing macroeconomic and geopolitical volatility around the world,” PVH Corp Chief Executive Emanuel Chirico said in a news release Wednesday.
column9: Many U.S. retailers are bracing for the impact of tariffs imposed by the Trump administration on Chinese goods.
column10: Chirico said about $400 million of its products are produced in China for the U.S. market.
column11: “There might be an impact from tariffs, although it’s not that big a component for us,” he told CNBC.
column12: PVH shares were down 1.6 percent in after-hours trading on Wednesday. The company’s shares are up roughly 13 percent year to date.
column13: PVH has invested in improving online and offline consumer experiences by making transactions easier. In doing so, the company said it can better target shoppers, especially younger generations.
column14: PVH said Calvin Klein’s sales rose 18 percent in the reported quarter, while Tommy Hilfiger reported sales growth of 15 percent.
column15: Net income attributable to the company rose to $165.2 million, or $2.12 per share, in the three months ended Aug. 5, from $119.7 million, or $1.52 per share, a year earlier.
column16: Excluding items, PVH earned $2.18 per share, 8 cents more than the average analyst estimate of $2.10, polled by Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column17: Net sales rose 13.2 percent to $2.22 billion.

column4: Calvin Klein owner PVH profit rises 38 pct
column5: Aug 29 (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp reported a 38 percent rise in second-quarter profit on Wednesday, helped by higher sales of its Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose to $165.2 million, or $2.12 per share, in the three months ended Aug. 5, from $119.7 million, or $1.52 per share, a year earlier.
column7: On an adjusted basis, the company earned $2.18 per share.
column8: Net sales rose 13.2 percent to $2.22 billion. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Sriraj Kalluvila)

column4: Calvin Klein owner PVH beats sales, profit estimates
column5: (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp PVH.N on Wednesday topped sales and profit estimates and raised its earnings forecasts for the year, driven by double-digit growth in Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands.
column6: The company now expects earnings of $9.05 to $9.15 per share, compared with its previous forecast of $9.00 to $9.10 per share.
column7: PVH said Calvin Klein’s sales rose 18 percent in the reported quarter, while Tommy Hilfiger reported sales growth of 21 percent.
column8: Net income attributable to the company rose to $179.4 million, or $2.29 per share, in the first quarter ended May 6 from $70.4 million, or 89 cents per share, a year earlier.
column9: Excluding items, PVH earned $2.36 per share, 11 cents more than the average analyst estimate, polled by Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.
column10: Net sales rose 16.4 percent to $2.31 billion, beating analysts’ expectation of $2.28 billion.
column11: Shares of the company were marginally lower at $154.72 in extended trading.

column4: Calvin Klein owner PVH tops first-quarter sales estimates
column5: May 30 (Reuters) - Apparel maker PVH Corp on Wednesday reported quarterly sales that beat Wall Street estimates, driven by demand for its Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brands.
column6: Net income attributable to the company rose to $179.4 million, or $2.29 per shares, in the first quarter ended May 6, from $70.4 million, or 89 cents per share, a year earlier.
column7: Net sales rose 16.4 percent to $2.31 billion, beating analysts’ expectation of $2.28 billion, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)
